title: Trump administration prepares to raid military projects for border wall
text:
A section of border wall in Sunland Park, New Mexico. | Mario Tama/Getty Images Congress Trump administration prepares to raid military projects for border wall

The Trump administration is executing its plan this week to suck $3.6 billion from military construction projects to build the border wall, calling lawmakers whose districts will take a hit, according to multiple House aides.

Defense Secretary Mark Esper called congressional leaders on Tuesday to detail the cash grab, a move likely to further inflame Democrats who have accused the administration of illegally overriding Congress’ spending decisions.

Story Continued Below

A total of 127 projects are affected, a Pentagon official told reporters Tuesday. Roughly $1.8 billion will come from military construction projects outside the United States and $1.8 billion will come from projects within the United States and its territories.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said Esper told him some of the money will come from the U.S. Military Academy at West Point in his home state.

“It is a slap in the face to the members of the Armed Forces who serve our country that President Trump is willing to cannibalize already allocated military funding to boost his own ego and for a wall he promised Mexico would pay to build,” Schumer wrote in a statement.

President Donald Trump declared a national emergency in February, commanding the diversion of $8 billion from various federal accounts to build a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border. Besides military construction projects, a Treasury Department account and Defense Department efforts to interdict drugs were affected by the presidential order.

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi informed House Democrats of the Pentagon's move on a conference call Tuesday afternoon. The Defense Department plans to start calling lawmakers Wednesday to deliver the bad news for districts that will lose out on millions of dollars for military bases and other defense installations at the expense of the president's signature campaign promise of erecting a wall dividing the United States from its southern neighbor.

It is still unclear how many districts will be affected, and House Democratic leaders do not yet have a list of the canceled projects, according to a senior aide.

Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz (D-Fla.), who oversees military construction funding in the House, warned that the Trump administration “is about to weaken our national security by stealing billions from our military," including training for soldiers and schools for military families.

“I reminded his Admin today that I will not support this theft from our military," Wasserman Schultz wrote on Twitter. "Trump can pander to his nativist base, but the House will fight his every attempt to make our military families or national security suffer as a result."

The Pentagon's list of projects that would be shorted under the national emergency declaration initially had nearly $12.9 billion worth of projects in dozens of states, as well as several locations overseas.

The move is expected to draw ire, at least privately, from Republicans as well. Lawmakers in both parties have consistently warned the Pentagon against raiding the defense budget for a border wall — a move they fear will hurt military readiness.
description: Defense Secretary Mark Esper called Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Tuesday to detail the cash grab.
